case_name: State of Andhra Pradesh v. Respondent No. 1 and Respondent No. 2

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 30, 1960 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Criminal Appeals Nos. 277 and 278 of 1957 and Criminal Revision Case No. 810 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 30, 1960 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court  in Criminal Appeals Nos. 277 and 278 of 1957 and Criminal Revision Case No. 810 of 1957.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 tried before the Court of Sessions, Visakhapatnam for offences under s. 120-B, s. 409, s. 477-A and s. 471 read with s. 467, I.P.C.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent No. I was tried before the Court of Sessions, Visakhapatnam for offences under s. 120-B, Indian Penal Code, s. 409, s. 477-A and s. 471 read with s. 467, I.P.C.

facts.text: Respondent No. 2 tried for offence under s. 120-B and offences under ss. 409 read with s. 109, 477-A and 471 read with s. 467, I.P.C.

anchor.surface_text: while respondent No. 2 was tried for an offence under s. 120-B and for offences under ss. 409 read with s. 109, 477-A and 471 read with s. 467, I.P.C.

facts.text: Each respondent convicted of first two offences; respondent No. 1 alone convicted of other two offences by Additional Sessions Judge, Visakhapatnam.

anchor.surface_text: Each of the respondents was convicted of the first two offences, but the respondent No. I alone was convicted of the other two offences.

facts.text: High Court allowed appeals, acquitted respondents and dismissed State's revision for enhancement of sentences.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court allowed the two appeals, acquitted the respondents and dismissed the application for revision preferred by the State.

facts.text: State of Andhra Pradesh appealed to Supreme Court by special leave under Art. 136.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Andhra Pradesh has come up before this Court in appeal by obtaining special leave under Art. 136 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Andhra Engineering Co. (AECO) formed in 1929 as private limited company from partnership by D.L.N. Raju.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1929 the Andhra Engineering Co., which was originally a partnership firm formed by one D.L.N. Raju was converted into a private limited, company

facts.text: VESCO floated in 1933 by Raju; AECO transferred Visakhapatnam licence to VESCO.

anchor.surface_text: Raju floated in the year 1933 a public limited company called Visakhapatnam Electric Supply Corporation Ltd.,  referred hereafter as VESCO

facts.text: Anakapalli Electric Supply Corporation Ltd. floated in 1936.

anchor.surface_text: and another in the year 1936 called the Anakapalli Electric Supply Corporation Ltd.

facts.text: AECO appointed Managing Agent for VESCO and others.

anchor.surface_text: The AECO was appointed Managing Agent for each of these corporations under separate agreements.

facts.text: D.L.N. Raju died in 1939; succeeded by R.K.N.G. Raju as Managing Director of AECO.

anchor.surface_text: first of whom was D.L.N. Raju. He died in the year 1939 and was succeeded by R.K.N.G. Raju, an Advocate of Rajahmundry.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 Ganeswara Rao appointed stenotypist in AECO in 1923, later Head Clerk, then Secretary of VESCO and representative of Managing Agents.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent No. 1, Ganeswara Rao was also an old employee of AECO, having been appointed a stenotypist in the year 1923 on an initial salary of Rs. 40/- p.m. Eventually he became the Head Clerk therein.

facts.text: Appointment of respondent No. 1 as Secretary of VESCO and representative not disputed.

anchor.surface_text: All this is not disputed.

facts.text: Conspiracy hatched in 1947 by respondent No. 1 with approver K.V. Ramana, respondent No. 2 Lakshminarayana Rao and others to misappropriate VESCO funds.

anchor.surface_text: According to the prosecution the respondent No. I took both the approver and Lakshminarayana Rao in his confidence as also some other persons known and unknown for carrying out his nefarious purpose, namely, the misappropriation of the funds of VESCO during the subsistence of AECOs managing agency of VESCO. The conspiracy is said to have been hatched in the year 1947

facts.text: Falsification of accounts and misappropriation continued till end of accounting year; total misappropriation Rs. 3,40,000.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of investigation they found that there was a total misappropriation of Rs. 3,40,000/-

facts.text: VESCO undertaking acquired by Government in June 1952.

anchor.surface_text: A mention may be made of the fact that in June, 1952 the VESCO undertaking was acquired by the Government under the provisions of the Electricity Undertaking Acquisition Act

facts.text: R.K.N.G. Raju died in April 1948.

anchor.surface_text: K.N.G. Raju took ill towards the end of 1947 and died at Madras in April, 1948.

facts.text: G.V. Subba Raju appointed Managing Director of AECO in middle of 1948.

anchor.surface_text: He agreed and was elected Managing Director of AECO in the middle of 1948.

facts.text: Complaint lodged with police by K.S. Dutt on May 19, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The Directors of VESCO thereafter authorised K. S. Dutt, one of the Directors to lodge a complaint with the police which he accordingly lodged on May 19, 1952.

facts.text: Chargesheet filed on May 13, 1954 against two respondents, Murty and approver Ramana.

anchor.surface_text: On May 13, 1954 a chargesheet was filed against the two respondents as well as Murti and the approver Ramana.

facts.text: Ramana granted pardon on November 17, 1954 after confession.

anchor.surface_text: The latter accordingly made a confession on November 15, 1954 and on November 17, 1954 the Additional District Magistrate  Independent  granted him pardon

facts.text: Total misappropriation found Rs. 3,40,000 by police investigation.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of investigation they found that there was a total misappropriation of Rs. 3,40,000/-

facts.text: General Body meeting on November 29, 1951 postponed to December 9, 1951 due to uproar over auditors report.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime on November 29, 1951 there was a meeting of the General Body at which the accounts were, among other things, to be considered. There was a considerable uproar at that meeting because the respondent No. 1 said that the Auditors report had not been received.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 paid Rs. 50,000 to Andhra Power System on April 30, 1952 from sale of his property.

anchor.surface_text: On April 30, 1952 the respondent No. 1, by selling some of his property, himself paid Rs. 50,000/- to the Andhra Power System towards the sum due to it from VESCO

issues.text: The first question for consideration is whether there was a misjoinder of parties and of persons.

anchor.surface_text: The first question for consideration is whether there was a misjoinder of parties and of persons. The first charge is in respect of the conspiracy alleged to have been entered into by the two respondents, K. V. Ramana, the approver, and others known and unknown to commit criminal breach of trust of the funds of VESCO and, in order to screen its detection, to falsify the accounts of VESCO and to use forged documents as genuine.

issues.text: Whether the provisions of the various clauses of s. 239 Cr.P.C. can be applied cumulatively or are mutually exclusive.

anchor.surface_text: In coming to the conclusion that the provisions of various clauses of s. 239 cannot be applied cumulatively the High Court has relied upon the decision in Re Vankavalapati Gopala Rao. There the learned judges have held thus These clauses are mutually exclusive and they cannot be simultaneously applied and to construe them as supplementing each other would be enlarging the scope of the exceptions.

issues.text: Whether s.239 Cr.P.C. is subject to the limitations of ss.233, 234, 235, 236 Cr.P.C.

anchor.surface_text: it is a rule of construction that all the provisions of a statute are to be read together and given effect to and that it is, therefore, the duty of the Court to construe a statute harmoniously. Thus, while it is clear that the sections preceding s. 239 have no overriding effect on that section,, the courts are not to ignore them but apply such of them as can be applied without detracting from the provisions of S.239.

issues.text: Whether a charge of conspiracy under s.120B IPC can be framed and maintained even after the substantive offences committed in pursuance thereof have been completed.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal conspiracy as defined in s. 120-A consists of an agreement to do an illegal act. Mr. Bhimasankaram, supporting the view taken by the High Court then contends that it is not permissible to frame a charge of conspiracy when the matter has proceeded beyond the stage of conspiracy and that in pursuance of it offences have actually been committed.

issues.text: Whether the examination of the respondents under s.342 Cr.P.C. was unfair or an abuse of power.

anchor.surface_text: examination of the respondent under s. 342 of the Code was unfair. Coming to the next point of Mr Bhimsankaram regarding the abuse of powers under s. 342 his first contention was that long and involved questions were put to the respondents.

issues.text: Whether the absence of entries in the account books of recipient firms is relevant evidence to prove non-payment under the Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: s. 34 of the Indian Evidence Act which reads thus Entries in books of account. There is s. 11 of the Evidence Act which provides that facts not otherwise relevant are relevant if they are inconsistent with any fact in issue or relevant fact.

issues.text: Whether irregularities in charges vitiate the conviction under s.537 Cr.P.C. without failure of justice.

anchor.surface_text: provisions of s. 537 of the Code as amended by Act 26 of 1955. Even if we were to assume that there has been a misjoinder of charges in violation of the provisions of ss. 233 to 239 of the Code, the High Court was incompetent to set aside the conviction of the respondents without coming to the definite conclusion that misjoinder had occasioned failure of justice.

arguments.claim: Joint trial of two or more persons in respect of different offences committed by each is illegal; s.239 CrPC provisions of no avail.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court set aside the conviction of the respondents on a number of grounds. In the first place according to the High Court, joint trial of two or more persons in respect of different offences committed by each of them is illegal and that here as they were charged with having committed offences under s. 120-B, s. 409, s. 477-A and s. 476/467, I.P.C. they could not be tried jointly. According to it the provisions of s. 239 were of no avail.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: is in respect of the companyspiracy alleged to have been entered into by the two respondents, K. V. Ramana, the approver, and others known and unknown

arguments.court_reasoning: s.239 clauses can be applied cumulatively; enabling provision; no misjoinder as offences part of same transaction/conspiracy.

arguments.claim: Even if s.239 applicable, subject to s.234 CrPC; trial for more than three offences impermissible.

anchor.surface_text: Next according to the High Court even if s. 239 is applicable its provisions are subject to those of s. 234 and as such the trial being for more than three offences was impermissible.

anchor.surface_text: Further, according to the High Court where a conspiracy has yielded its fruits the conspirators can be charged with the actual offences committed and not with conspiracy to commit those offences.

anchor.surface_text: Charge of conspiracy... can be validly made only when the prosecution establishes that every conspirator expected to receive a personal benefit from it and that the prosecution has not been able to establish that the respondent No. 2 or the approver...

arguments.claim: Resp No.2 charged with s.409 IPC cannot be convicted of mere abetment.

anchor.surface_text: In so far as the respondent No. 2 is concerned the High Court has held that since he was charged with a specific offence under s.409 I.P.C. he could not be convicted of mere abetment of an offence.

arguments.claim: No duty on court to inform accused of s.342(4) right to give evidence.

holdings.text: There was no misjoinder of parties or charges as the offences were committed in the course of the same transaction involving conspiracy.

anchor.surface_text: The first question for consideration is whether there was a misjoinder of parties and of persons. The first charge is in respect of the conspiracy alleged to have been entered into by the two respondents, K. V. Ramana, the approver, and others known and unknown to commit criminal breach of trust of the funds of VESCO and, in order to screen its detection, to falsify the accounts of VESCO and to use forged documents as genuine.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Offences under conspiracy charge and substantive offences form same transaction; s.239(d) and other clauses permit joint trial; no prejudice caused.

holdings.text: Provisions of various clauses of s.239 Cr.P.C. can be applied cumulatively and are not mutually exclusive.

anchor.surface_text: In coming to the conclusion that the provisions of various clauses of s. 239 cannot be applied cumulatively the High Court has relied upon the decision in Re Vankavalapati Gopala Rao. There the learned judges have held thus These clauses are mutually exclusive and they cannot be simultaneously applied and to construe them as supplementing each other would be enlarging the scope of the exceptions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Grammatical construction uses 'and' not 'or'; enabling provision; rejects High Court precedents like Vankavalapati; follows Allahabad HC and own precedents.

holdings.text: s.239 Cr.P.C. is not subject to overriding limitations of ss.233, 234, 235, 236; earlier sections apply only so far as may be.

anchor.surface_text: it is a rule of construction that all the provisions of a statute are to be read together and given effect to and that it is, therefore, the duty of the Court to construe a statute harmoniously. Thus, while it is clear that the sections preceding s. 239 have no overriding effect on that section,, the courts are not to ignore them but apply such of them as can be applied without detracting from the provisions of S.239.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction; s.239 enabling and overriding; avoids anomaly where joint offenders face fewer limits than single; 'so far as may be' qualifies.

holdings.text: Charge of criminal conspiracy under s.120B IPC is maintainable even after substantive offences committed in pursuance thereof.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal conspiracy as defined in s. 120-A consists of an agreement to do an illegal act. Mr. Bhimasankaram, supporting the view taken by the High Court then contends that it is not permissible to frame a charge of conspiracy when the matter has proceeded beyond the stage of conspiracy and that in pursuance of it offences have actually been committed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Conspiracy independent offence per s.120A/B; liability persists post-execution; follows Kandimalla Subbaiah, Swamirathnam, Natwarlal.

holdings.text: Examination of accused under s.342 Cr.P.C. was not unfair or abuse of power.

anchor.surface_text: examination of the respondent under s. 342 of the Code was unfair. Coming to the next point of Mr Bhimsankaram regarding the abuse of powers under s. 342 his first contention was that long and involved questions were put to the respondents.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accused understood long questions and answered; written statements filed; documents accessible; no cross-exam; no prejudice; no duty to highlight s.342(4).

holdings.text: Absence of entries in recipients' account books relevant to disprove payments under s.11 Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: s. 34 of the Indian Evidence Act which reads thus Entries in books of account. There is s. 11 of the Evidence Act which provides that facts not otherwise relevant

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.34 relevant for existing entries only; s.11 admits facts inconsistent with fact in issue (payments made); absence inconsistent with receipt.

holdings.text: Irregularities in charges or procedure do not vitiate conviction under s.537 Cr.P.C. absent failure of justice.

anchor.surface_text: provisions of s. 537 of the Code as amended by Act 26 of 1955. Even if we were to assume that there has been a misjoinder of charges in violation of the provisions of ss. 233 to 239 of the Code, the High Court was incompetent to set aside the conviction of the respondents without coming to the definite conclusion that misjoinder had occasioned failure of justice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.537 curative; requires actual prejudice/failure of justice; High Court made no such finding; follows Willie Slaney, Birichh Bhuian.

holdings.text: Court has no duty under s.342(4) Cr.P.C. to inform accused of right to give sworn evidence.

anchor.surface_text: Finally we are clear that it was not the duty of the court to draw the pointed attention of the respondents to the provisions of sub-s. 4 of s. 342 and tell them that they may, if they chose, enter the witness box.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Provision removes ban but imposes no affirmative duty on court; counsel aware; no complaint of ignorance or prejudice.

anchor.surface_text: it is a rule of construction that all the provisions of a statute are to be read together and given effect to and that it is, therefore, the duty of the Court to construe a statute harmoniously. Thus, while it is clear that the sections preceding s. 239 have no overriding effect on that section,, the courts are not to ignore them but apply such of them as can be applied without detracting from the provisions of S.239.
